note.p: MS Walters 143, Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. Paris, mid-14th c.
Parchment, 289 x 205 mm, 143 folios.

Parchment in fair but sound condition; some wormholes near front and back; parchment often has browned, mottled appearance; vertical repair at fol. 143; repairs include those at bottom of 1, 27, and 29.
143 - single added leaf

A number of signatures survive, e.g. aiiii (fol. 4r), b-biiii (fols. 9-12), etc. (alphabet skips J). Catchwords, lower right, many partially cropped; most catchwords boxed in double lines. Modern pagination, top right in pencil, is correct; an earlier pagination in ink, roman numerals – the ink foliation inadvertently skips iiiixxxvii, and thus the two foliations differ from there to end (pace Randall in Medieval and Renaissance manuscripts in the Walters Art Gallery, which states that the earlier foliation inadvertently skips iiiixxvii).

Ruled in brown ink. Eight vertical through lines – one each to define two edges of columns, and two to separate first letter of each line from rest of line. One horizontal through line at top of text block (none at bottom). Although the intention seems for the space between two columns to have been left blank, ruled lines for text sometimes extend out into the space irregularly, e.g. 47r. Text block measures 215 x 155 mm., 2 columns of 40 lines; each column app. 70 mm in width, right column sometimes slightly larger; verticals set [5|3|62|13|5|3|63] mm. apart (Randall has it as [6|3|62|12|6|3|62] mm.].)

One scribe throughout (note that right edge of fol. 143 has been cropped away, resulting in loss of text – this has been patched with a strip of parchment, and the missing text filled in on the replacement parchment in a later hand, black ink). Textualis, brown ink, little to no punctuation. Struck through line on 52r; subpuncted 5v, 43r; diagonal slashes through columns on 30v and 31r, but not clear why these are present; corrections in later hand, black ink, on 50r; first letter of line overwritten in darker ink on 135r.

Textual divisions and changes in speaker in red. First letter of each line touched in yellow if not otherwise decorated. 9-line initial on fol. 1r beneath frontispiece – blue letter against reddish-purple background, letter and background outlined in black, white penwork decoration; area inside of lobes of letter (M) filled with blue/white- and orange/white-leafed vines against gold leaf background. 2/3-line initials follow panel miniatures, alternating pink letters with blue and gold backgrounds and blue letters with pink and gold backgrounds; infilled with blue, pink and orange vine and trifoliate or heart-shaped leaf designs, white penwork decoration, heart-shaped leaf extenders. Elsewhere, 2-line initials alternating red with blue decorative penwork and blue with red decorative penwork.

3-sided bar border on fol. 1r – frame on left, bottom, and right, with vines only (no frame) at top. On left, frame alternates blue/reddish-purple and reddish-purple/blue, some white penwork decoration. On bottom and right, gold in center with green on either side. On bottom and right, frame connects roundels containing busts, all facing right; heads against gold background surrounded by, alternately, reddish-purple and blue quatrefoil roundels. One head at lower left corner (bearded man), one at lower right corner (bearded man?, heavily abraded), one at top right corner (cleric?, abraded), one in lower center (young woman or man), and two spaced, centered, along right edge (bearded men, abraded). On left and top, blue vines with orange and gold heart-shaped leaves. On bottom and right, thin black tendrils extend from frame with alternating green and gold trifoliate leaves.

42 miniatures – 1 of these the large frontispiece spanning two columns (100 x 152 mm), and 41 panel miniatures spanning one column each (7-12 lines in height). Frontispiece on fol. 1r – blue border with spiral pattern in white at top and bottom and reddish-purple border with white spiral pattern at sides, outlined in double lines of black with gold boxes at its edges. Four scenes within, divided by green borders outlined in black; each scene has gold background; predominant colors are mauve, blue, green, orange; white and black ink used for detail. Panel miniatures on fols. 2r, 2v, 3r, 3v, 4r, 4v, 5v, 6v, 8r, 19v, 20r, 20v, 21r, 21v, 22r, 22v, 23r, 23v, 24r, 24v, 25v, 26v, 29r, 34r, 39r, 49r, 62v, 69v, 72v, 81v, 98r, 101v, 105v, 110v, 128r, 136v, 139r, 139v – reddish-purple and/or blue borders, spiral patterns in white, outlined in double lines of black ink, gold boxes at the corners. Backgrounds of miniatures are entirely gold or geometric patterns in a variety of colors and gold. Aspects of figures, including facial features, hair, and costume delineated in brown or black ink. Leather tabs, added later, mark folios with miniatures.

Mostly female personifications, but Fausemblant is a Dominican friar and Contreinte Atenance is a Franciscan on 69v, 72v, 81v. Fausemblant defaced on 69v and 72v, later redrawn with lighter, grayish-brown ink.

Added at bottom of 69v, rather early – a miniature of a seated man in Dominican habit embracing a woman in red robe; woman’s face not visible – is perhaps under hood of Dominican’s robe. At bottom of 72v, another miniature, presumably added at same time, shows a dog in Dominican habit followed by three smaller dogs. Written beside this is Veni mecum. This is perhaps a visual pun on Domini canes, i.e. dogs of God.
Panel miniature and initial on 24v severely damaged. Areas of pigment have flaked off in many scenes.

Linked by Alfred Kuhn ("Die Illustration des Rosenromans") to other Roman de la Rose manuscripts such as Chantilly, Musée Condé, 664 (attributed to Richard de Montbaston), with a frontispiece also divided into four compartments and Amans with Dangier in the first.

Randall found similarities between this and Capetown, South African Public Library, MS G 4c 12. According to Randall, the illuminations were done by several collaborating artists working in Paris under north French influence. Randall offers 21r and 29r as evidence of different but stylistically close hands at work.

Miniatures attributed by Richard and Mary Rouse (Manuscripts and their Makers) to Jeanne de Montbaston (fl. 1338-1353). It is thought Jeanne worked alone on four other Rose manuscripts (Düsseldorf, Bibliothek der Staatlichen Kunstakademie, A. B.142; Madrid, Biblioteca nacional, 10032; New York, Morgan Library & Museum, M. 503; Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, fr. 802), and together with her husband Richard on four more Rose manuscripts (Paris, Bibliothèque de l’Arsenal, 5226; Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, fr. 25526; and Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, Smith Lesouëf 62).

France, 18th c. (according to Randall), 300 mm. in height, 235 mm. from center of spine to fore edge. Brown leather, probably sheepskin, rectangular boards, five raised bands on spine (partially recessed), headband and tailband of white thread. Front and back covers have simple frame consisting of single blind-tooled fillet. Spine features gold-tooled designs, now badly faded/deteriorated and hard to make out, in the first and third through sixth compartments. At both top and bottom of spine, two simple blind-stamped lines. In second compartment, red leather title label with two gold-tooled lines each at top and bottom of compartment, and the following title: LE ROMAN / DE / LA ROSE. Fore, top, and bottom edges marbled in red, now quite faded. One paper flyleaf each, front and back; other half of each bifolium used as pastedown in front and back. According to Randall, watermark in front flyleaf of a bunch or grapes in rows of 1,2,3,4,4,3,2,1.
1. From Randall catalogue:

Completed in Paris (?) under north French influence c. 1340-50. Modern entries concerning author and contents on front pastedown and f. A. Perhaps owned by Léon Gruel, Paris bookbinder and bookseller, s. XIX/XX (3-page written description with no identifying marks, WAG file, p. I formerly affixed to front pastedown, a practice generally observed in manuscripts acquired from Gruel). Purchased between 1895 and 1931.
2. ex-libris of Henry Walters on front pastedown
3. On the front pastedown in pencil:

Jehan de Meung Le Roman de la Rose Manuscrit sur [?] parchemin de la fin du XIIIe siecle ecrit en France orne d’une grande page Jean [de ?] Meun ne vers 1240 est mort 1305 ce livre a [illegible] écrit [illegible] …ant
4. On flyleaf 1r in black ink:

Le Roman de la Rose commencé par Guillaume de Lorris et achevé par Jean Clopinel surnommé de Meun. Guillaume de Lorris mourut en 1260 et Jean de Meun lacheva 40 ans apres. Guillaume de Lorris vivoit sous le regne de St Louis et Jean de Meun sous Philippe le Bel
Contains only Roman de la Rose.

Wide variety of no[ta] tags in margins in a number of hands: e.g. 21v; hand with pointing finger: 30v (beneath hand is written va). Marginal paraph marks at 59v, 60r, 93v. Annotations include "Non de vraye amittie" on 33r and "Car amoy si grant amour a" on 62r.
Description by Timothy L. Stinson
